data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: Both Alba Mineral Resources and GreenRoc Mining appear to be positioned ahead of the market rather than behind it. In each case, the strategic logic is largely in place: asset exposure aligned to long-term demand trends, improving regulatory and geopolitical tailwinds, and a narrative that makes increasing sense as energy transition, supply-chain security, and critical materials move from policy discussion to execution. The challenge is not direction, but timing. Markets are often slow to price early positioning. Recognition typically follows validation — milestones reached, risk retired, and external conditions converging. When that happens, perception can shift quickly, not because the fundamentals changed overnight, but because they finally became visible. In that sense, both companies look less like speculative plays and more like options on inevitability — waiting for the market to catch up with what is already forming. Right place. Right time. Recognition pending.
data.thread_title: Right Assets, Right Timing — Market Recognition Pending

data.content: Motzfeldt greenland rare earth minerals The Motzfeldt system in Greenland is a significant site for rare earth minerals, particularly niobium and rare earth elements (REEs). The Motzfeldt Deposit, located in the Gardar Province, is home to a substantial defined JORC Mineral Resource of 340 million tonnes, which includes 1,564,000 tonnes of zirconium, 884,000 tonnes of total rare earth oxides, 629,000 tonnes of niobium, and 41,000 tonnes of tantalum. The system's unique geological processes have mobilized and reconcentrated these minerals, making it a key player in the global rare earth supply chain https://albamineralresources.com/motzfeldt-critical-metals-project

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: Tuesday, 3 February 2026 🌄 The Horizon Knowledge Gateway — Finance & Economics Series Debt, Monetary Drift, and the Repricing of Scarcity Recent volatility in gold, silver, and critical minerals markets reflects a system under monetary strain, not a breakdown in fundamentals. Decades of debt accumulation, reinforced by ultra-loose monetary policy, have left central banks constrained. Tightening risks destabilising highly leveraged economies; easing accelerates currency debasement. In such conditions, volatility becomes structural. This is not unprecedented. Following the collapse of the Bretton Woods system in 1971, monetary discipline eroded, and real assets repriced sharply. Gold, silver, and energy did not surge due to speculation, but because fiat anchors were removed while fiscal expansion continued. Today’s environment rhymes. Debt levels are historically elevated, real yields struggle to remain positive, and commodities are increasingly priced through leveraged paper markets. In silver, futures volumes frequently exceed annual physical production—disconnecting short-term price action from underlying scarcity. Yet scarcity does not disappear. It accumulates. Industrial demand tied to electrification, defence, and supply-chain resilience is rising, while mining investment remains constrained. Historically, such imbalances have resolved not through policy finesse but through repricing. Volatility redistributes ownership from those reacting to leverage and policy noise to those aligned with structural reality. As Jesse Livermore observed: “Be right and sit tight.” Debt can be extended. Currencies can be managed. Scarcity cannot be printed. — Michael G. Harvey 🌄 The Horizon Knowledge Gateway

data.content: "Motzfeldt one of only five CRM projects in Greenland granted "very large deposit" status by GEUS (Danish & Greenlandic Geological Survey), and one of only two multi-element CRM projects with scale". Reminder that the £550k placing at 0.017p made at the time of the 14/07/25 RNS went to institutional investors and included 1 warrant for 2 placing shares exercisable within 2 years at 0.0255p. The share is currently very close to this exercise price. The warrants constitute, in their nature, a staggered placing when exercised.

data.author: ocelot
data.content: One doesn't need to make a placing to raise cash if one is paying in shares. In addition to the resolution re the acquisition of Motzfeldt, there are 2 standard resolutions authorising the board to issue new shares and to make placings. At some stage, there will doubtless be a new placing, because overheads do need to be paid and Alba is not yet generating any revenue on a regular basis. But a brief perusal of this board over the last few weeks will show that nobody has any idea when the next placing might take place.

data.author: ocelot
data.content: Agree with another poster, think Clogau may contain as much gold as has already been extracted in the past, about 80,000 ounces. At £4,000 an ounce, puts a gross valuation on Clogau at the spot price of £320m before extraction costs, of course, but before, also, the Clogau premium. Means the potential value of Clogau to Alba is well in excess of £1bn, much more than the net present value of its stake in GROC, about $200m. And then there is Motzfeldt. The stock remains grossly undervalued, imho.

data.content: The parabolic rise in gold is actually starting to become a little troubling. Is it just the result of the US wanting a weaker dollar plus geopolitical tensions, or is it presaging a paradigm shift in the global economy away from fiat money into asset backed currencies?  The central banks have certainly been steadily buying gold over the last few years. Or worse is it the Canary in the coalmine warning of a pending economic collapse as in 2007/8? data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: Heavy volume trading shows ALBA being actively worked between 0.030–0.033, with no sign of panic. A large 29.6m block at ~0.0306 was absorbed without price collapse, suggesting a negotiated transfer rather than dumping. Repeated multi-million BUY prints above 0.030 and structured clearing around 13:17 indicate strong absorption of supply, with 0.030 acting as defended support and 0.033 as the near-term ceiling. This looks like positioning and base-building, not distribution — if selling pressure continues to fade and 0.033 starts to hold as bid, the structure remains constructive.

data.author: michty26
data.content: Vein Continuity: Veins are not uniformly filled with gold; they often contain, or "shoots" of high-grade ore, which might stop, start, or continue for hundreds of meters along a strike. In short, gold veins can continue far deeper than humans can currently mine, but 4–5 km represents the current practical limit of engineering, heat management, and profitability.

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: The trade data shows very heavy intraday volume clustered between 0.022 and 0.024, indicating an active battle between supply and demand rather than directional exhaustion. Key observations: Large sell blocks dominate the mid-session (multiple 5–14m trades around 0.0227–0.023), suggesting overhang from existing holders distributing into strength. Despite this, sizeable buy orders repeatedly absorbed supply at 0.0238–0.024, including multiple 1–10m buys, indicating institutional or coordinated accumulation rather than retail flow. The late trade at 16:29 (9.6m buy at 0.0235) after sustained selling is notable—it suggests dip-buying rather than capitulation. The bid–ask remained relatively tight (0.022-0.024) throughout, suggesting liquidity resilience rather than disorderly selling. Interpretation This looks like a distribution-to-absorption phase, not a breakdown. Supply is being met with demand, but price is capped near 0.024, confirming it as a near-term resistance zone. Conclusion Below 0.022 → sellers likely retain control Sustained holds above 0.024 → supply likely exhausted A clean break would require continued volume-led absorption, not just isolated buys In short, pressure is being absorbed, but the market is not yet free of supply.

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: If Alba Mineral Resources were to decisively break and hold above 0.026, the initial impact would likely be technical rather than fundamental. That level acts as a known resistance point. A clean break with volume would suggest that selling pressure has been absorbed, often attracting momentum traders and short-term liquidity, increasing volatility. What typically follows is a test of the breakout—pullbacks to see whether 0.026 holds as support. If it does, confidence improves and price discovery can continue toward the next resistance area. What it would not, on its own, mean is a fundamental re-rating. Sustained upside would still depend on news flow, execution, and broader market sentiment. In short: A break above 0.026 would signal improving sentiment, not a valuation conclusion.

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: Add a comment… Open Emoji Keyboard View Michael Harvey’s  graphic link Michael Harvey • You Author & Educator | Founder, The Horizon Knowledge Gateway | Sharing Global Expertise Beyond Engineering 1s For Alba Mineral Resources, a potential US move to secure mineral rights in Greenland would likely be strategically positive in the medium term, though not without qualifiers. On the upside, it would materially de-risk the geopolitical narrative around Greenland-based assets. That shift could improve access to capital, strengthen offtake discussions, and attract strategic partners aligned with US and allied critical-minerals policy. Market perception would likely move from frontier optionality to strategic relevance. However, this would not represent an automatic value unlock. Licensing frameworks, Greenlandic and Danish sovereignty protections, ESG standards, and development timelines would remain decisive. US involvement would more likely increase scrutiny and compliance expectations than accelerate production. In summary: ✔️ Stronger strategic backdrop and investor interest ⚠️ Higher expectations on governance, ESG, and execution ⏳ Value creation driven by alignment and delivery—not headlines Greenland exposure would become more investable, but also more demanding. Michael G. Harvey

data.content: I asked chat gpt about the linkedin entry " was a Non-Executive Director of European Lithium Limited from October 2014 to November 2017". The reply says there were two roles. Different legal entity = different timeline The LinkedIn entry likely refers to:European Lithium Limited (ASX parent company in Australia) → Non-Exec Director → Oct 2014 – Nov 2017 That aligns with when European Lithium was restructuring its Austrian lithium project.But the Companies House record you linked is: European Lithium Limited – UK Establishment (FC032197) That is a separate legal registration of the overseas company operating in the UK. It’s completely possible that:He stopped being a board director of the Australian parent in 2017,but remained (or was later appointed as) a director of the UK registered branch Those are legally distinct roles.

data.author: ocelot
data.content: Company comment on Motzfeldt acquisition “The Company is delighted to have agreed to acquire a significant interest in the Motzfeldt Project, which offers scale, strategic metals, and a stable jurisdiction — a rare combination in today’s critical minerals landscape. Motzfeldt’s multi-commodity potential, particularly in niobium, tantalum, zirconium and rare earths, positions us strongly to support the transition to a low-carbon global economy. We look forward to accelerating exploration and development and unlocking Motzfeldt’s considerable value. “In addition to Motzfeldt’s strategic geology and resource base, its alignment with the critical raw material priorities of governments in the US, UK, EU, and other allied economies opens up the possibility of public and institutional support for the project. This offers us a significant opportunity — the potential to access grant funding, development loans, or strategic partnerships, which would enable us to advance the project with far less dilution than would traditionally be required on the public markets. This is a compelling differentiator.” (from the website/Critical Raw Materials/Motzfeldt) https://albamineralresources.com/company-comment

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: Both Alba Mineral Resources and GreenRoc Mining appear to be positioned ahead of the market rather than behind it. In each case, the strategic logic is largely in place: asset exposure aligned to long-term demand trends, improving regulatory and geopolitical tailwinds, and a narrative that makes increasing sense as energy transition, supply-chain security, and critical materials move from policy discussion to execution. The challenge is not direction, but timing. Markets are often slow to price early positioning. Recognition typically follows validation — milestones reached, risk retired, and external conditions converging. When that happens, perception can shift quickly, not because the fundamentals changed overnight, but because they finally became visible. In that sense, both companies look less like speculative plays and more like options on inevitability — waiting for the market to catch up with what is already forming. Right place. Right time. Recognition pending.
data.thread_title: Right Assets, Right Timing — Market Recognition Pending

data.author: one4one
data.content: Motzfeldt greenland rare earth minerals The Motzfeldt system in Greenland is a significant site for rare earth minerals, particularly niobium and rare earth elements (REEs). The Motzfeldt Deposit, located in the Gardar Province, is home to a substantial defined JORC Mineral Resource of 340 million tonnes, which includes 1,564,000 tonnes of zirconium, 884,000 tonnes of total rare earth oxides, 629,000 tonnes of niobium, and 41,000 tonnes of tantalum. The system's unique geological processes have mobilized and reconcentrated these minerals, making it a key player in the global rare earth supply chain https://albamineralresources.com/motzfeldt-critical-metals-project

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: Tuesday, 3 February 2026 🌄 The Horizon Knowledge Gateway — Finance & Economics Series Debt, Monetary Drift, and the Repricing of Scarcity Recent volatility in gold, silver, and critical minerals markets reflects a system under monetary strain, not a breakdown in fundamentals. Decades of debt accumulation, reinforced by ultra-loose monetary policy, have left central banks constrained. Tightening risks destabilising highly leveraged economies; easing accelerates currency debasement. In such conditions, volatility becomes structural. This is not unprecedented. Following the collapse of the Bretton Woods system in 1971, monetary discipline eroded, and real assets repriced sharply. Gold, silver, and energy did not surge due to speculation, but because fiat anchors were removed while fiscal expansion continued. Today’s environment rhymes. Debt levels are historically elevated, real yields struggle to remain positive, and commodities are increasingly priced through leveraged paper markets. In silver, futures volumes frequently exceed annual physical production—disconnecting short-term price action from underlying scarcity. Yet scarcity does not disappear. It accumulates. Industrial demand tied to electrification, defence, and supply-chain resilience is rising, while mining investment remains constrained. Historically, such imbalances have resolved not through policy finesse but through repricing. Volatility redistributes ownership from those reacting to leverage and policy noise to those aligned with structural reality. As Jesse Livermore observed: “Be right and sit tight.” Debt can be extended. Currencies can be managed. Scarcity cannot be printed. — Michael G. Harvey 🌄 The Horizon Knowledge Gateway

data.content: Is there still gold in the ground? There may be: Previous geological reports suggested as much as 500,000 ounces of gold could lie in unworked portions of the mine area. Modern exploration (including drilling, blasting and bulk sampling) is underway to assess this potential.

data.author: ocelot
data.content: Agree with another poster, think Clogau may contain as much gold as has already been extracted in the past, about 80,000 ounces. At £4,000 an ounce, puts a gross valuation on Clogau at the spot price of £320m before extraction costs, of course, but before, also, the Clogau premium. Means the potential value of Clogau to Alba is well in excess of £1bn, much more than the net present value of its stake in GROC, about $200m. And then there is Motzfeldt. The stock remains grossly undervalued, imho.

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: Heavy volume trading shows ALBA being actively worked between 0.030–0.033, with no sign of panic. A large 29.6m block at ~0.0306 was absorbed without price collapse, suggesting a negotiated transfer rather than dumping. Repeated multi-million BUY prints above 0.030 and structured clearing around 13:17 indicate strong absorption of supply, with 0.030 acting as defended support and 0.033 as the near-term ceiling. This looks like positioning and base-building, not distribution — if selling pressure continues to fade and 0.033 starts to hold as bid, the structure remains constructive.
data.thread_title: ALBA Tape Shows Controlled Accumulation, Not Panic

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: Summary: Early ALBA trading shows heavy selling being absorbed without a price collapse, with the stock tightly held between 0.033–0.035. Large sell blocks were cleared early, while repeated, structured buying at 0.035 suggests accumulation rather than panic. Price action is controlled and constructive, indicating positioning by stronger hands. If selling pressure fades and the bid lifts, 0.035 is likely to become support rather than resistance.

data.content: Vein Continuity: Veins are not uniformly filled with gold; they often contain, or "shoots" of high-grade ore, which might stop, start, or continue for hundreds of meters along a strike. In short, gold veins can continue far deeper than humans can currently mine, but 4–5 km represents the current practical limit of engineering, heat management, and profitability.

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: The trade data shows very heavy intraday volume clustered between 0.022 and 0.024, indicating an active battle between supply and demand rather than directional exhaustion. Key observations: Large sell blocks dominate the mid-session (multiple 5–14m trades around 0.0227–0.023), suggesting overhang from existing holders distributing into strength. Despite this, sizeable buy orders repeatedly absorbed supply at 0.0238–0.024, including multiple 1–10m buys, indicating institutional or coordinated accumulation rather than retail flow. The late trade at 16:29 (9.6m buy at 0.0235) after sustained selling is notable—it suggests dip-buying rather than capitulation. The bid–ask remained relatively tight (0.022-0.024) throughout, suggesting liquidity resilience rather than disorderly selling. Interpretation This looks like a distribution-to-absorption phase, not a breakdown. Supply is being met with demand, but price is capped near 0.024, confirming it as a near-term resistance zone. Conclusion Below 0.022 → sellers likely retain control Sustained holds above 0.024 → supply likely exhausted A clean break would require continued volume-led absorption, not just isolated buys In short, pressure is being absorbed, but the market is not yet free of supply.

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: If Alba Mineral Resources were to decisively break and hold above 0.026, the initial impact would likely be technical rather than fundamental. That level acts as a known resistance point. A clean break with volume would suggest that selling pressure has been absorbed, often attracting momentum traders and short-term liquidity, increasing volatility. What typically follows is a test of the breakout—pullbacks to see whether 0.026 holds as support. If it does, confidence improves and price discovery can continue toward the next resistance area. What it would not, on its own, mean is a fundamental re-rating. Sustained upside would still depend on news flow, execution, and broader market sentiment. In short: A break above 0.026 would signal improving sentiment, not a valuation conclusion.

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: Add a comment… Open Emoji Keyboard View Michael Harvey’s  graphic link Michael Harvey • You Author & Educator | Founder, The Horizon Knowledge Gateway | Sharing Global Expertise Beyond Engineering 1s For Alba Mineral Resources, a potential US move to secure mineral rights in Greenland would likely be strategically positive in the medium term, though not without qualifiers. On the upside, it would materially de-risk the geopolitical narrative around Greenland-based assets. That shift could improve access to capital, strengthen offtake discussions, and attract strategic partners aligned with US and allied critical-minerals policy. Market perception would likely move from frontier optionality to strategic relevance. However, this would not represent an automatic value unlock. Licensing frameworks, Greenlandic and Danish sovereignty protections, ESG standards, and development timelines would remain decisive. US involvement would more likely increase scrutiny and compliance expectations than accelerate production. In summary: ✔️ Stronger strategic backdrop and investor interest ⚠️ Higher expectations on governance, ESG, and execution ⏳ Value creation driven by alignment and delivery—not headlines Greenland exposure would become more investable, but also more demanding. Michael G. Harvey

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: This is not investment advice — simply my personal view. I believe Alba Mineral Resources will ultimately demonstrate that the gold at Clogau has commercial value, transforming the asset from a historic curiosity into an economically meaningful project. On its own, that would warrant a meaningful re-rating. More importantly, I see growing US and broader Western strategic interest in Greenland’s critical minerals—driven by supply-chain security and the need to reduce reliance on China—as a genuine structural shift rather than a passing narrative. Within that context, Alba’s Greenland exposure and its shareholding in GreenRoc Strategic Materials increasingly resemble strategic entry points rather than long-dated speculative assets. My view is that this combination—commercial gold potential in Wales and geopolitically significant minerals in Greenland—increases the likelihood that larger players will step in, whether through partnerships or outright acquisitions, rather than these assets remaining underfunded and diluted over time. This is simply my interpretation of how geology and geopolitics may intersect, and why I believe Alba’s risk profile is evolving from speculative toward strategic.

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: Well said, Ocelot. The market is currently valuing Alba as though commercial gold is impossible, not merely unproven. That is a strong assumption. If you believe the geology and ongoing work still offer a realistic path to success, then much of the downside is already reflected in the price, while the upside remains largely unrecognised. Add to that a US dollar in a clear downward trend — a backdrop that has historically favoured higher gold prices — and the asymmetry becomes even more pronounced. In that context, the shares represent a long-dated option on gold, acquired for next to nothing, at a time when the metal itself already commands a substantial premium.
data.thread_title: When Unproven Is Priced as Impossible

data.author: ocelot
data.content: Motzfeldt Critical Metals Project in southern Greenland Alba Mineral Resources plc has acquired a 51% controlling interest in the Motzfeldt Critical Metals Project in southern Greenland. The project provides exposure to four critical raw materials: niobium, tantalum, zirconium and rare earth elements, which are essential for clean energy, advanced technology and defence applications. https://albamineralresources.com/motzfeldt-critical-metals-project

data.author: ocelot
data.content: Company comment on Motzfeldt acquisition “The Company is delighted to have agreed to acquire a significant interest in the Motzfeldt Project, which offers scale, strategic metals, and a stable jurisdiction — a rare combination in today’s critical minerals landscape. Motzfeldt’s multi-commodity potential, particularly in niobium, tantalum, zirconium and rare earths, positions us strongly to support the transition to a low-carbon global economy. We look forward to accelerating exploration and development and unlocking Motzfeldt’s considerable value. “In addition to Motzfeldt’s strategic geology and resource base, its alignment with the critical raw material priorities of governments in the US, UK, EU, and other allied economies opens up the possibility of public and institutional support for the project. This offers us a significant opportunity — the potential to access grant funding, development loans, or strategic partnerships, which would enable us to advance the project with far less dilution than would traditionally be required on the public markets. This is a compelling differentiator.” (from the website/Critical Raw Materials/Motzfeldt) https://albamineralresources.com/company-comment

data.author: ocelot
data.content: Motzfeldt Critical Metals Project in southern Greenland Alba Mineral Resources plc has acquired a 51% controlling interest in the Motzfeldt Critical Metals Project in southern Greenland. The project provides exposure to four critical raw materials: niobium, tantalum, zirconium and rare earth elements, which are essential for clean energy, advanced technology and defence applications. https://albamineralresources.com/motzfeldt-critical-metals-project

data.author: ocelot
data.content: Company comment on Motzfeldt acquisition “The Company is delighted to have agreed to acquire a significant interest in the Motzfeldt Project, which offers scale, strategic metals, and a stable jurisdiction — a rare combination in today’s critical minerals landscape. Motzfeldt’s multi-commodity potential, particularly in niobium, tantalum, zirconium and rare earths, positions us strongly to support the transition to a low-carbon global economy. We look forward to accelerating exploration and development and unlocking Motzfeldt’s considerable value. “In addition to Motzfeldt’s strategic geology and resource base, its alignment with the critical raw material priorities of governments in the US, UK, EU, and other allied economies opens up the possibility of public and institutional support for the project. This offers us a significant opportunity — the potential to access grant funding, development loans, or strategic partnerships, which would enable us to advance the project with far less dilution than would traditionally be required on the public markets. This is a compelling differentiator.” (from the website/Critical Raw Materials/Motzfeldt) https://albamineralresources.com/company-comment

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: Both Alba Mineral Resources and GreenRoc Mining appear to be positioned ahead of the market rather than behind it. In each case, the strategic logic is largely in place: asset exposure aligned to long-term demand trends, improving regulatory and geopolitical tailwinds, and a narrative that makes increasing sense as energy transition, supply-chain security, and critical materials move from policy discussion to execution. The challenge is not direction, but timing. Markets are often slow to price early positioning. Recognition typically follows validation — milestones reached, risk retired, and external conditions converging. When that happens, perception can shift quickly, not because the fundamentals changed overnight, but because they finally became visible. In that sense, both companies look less like speculative plays and more like options on inevitability — waiting for the market to catch up with what is already forming. Right place. Right time. Recognition pending.
data.thread_title: Right Assets, Right Timing — Market Recognition Pending

data.author: one4one
data.content: Motzfeldt greenland rare earth minerals The Motzfeldt system in Greenland is a significant site for rare earth minerals, particularly niobium and rare earth elements (REEs). The Motzfeldt Deposit, located in the Gardar Province, is home to a substantial defined JORC Mineral Resource of 340 million tonnes, which includes 1,564,000 tonnes of zirconium, 884,000 tonnes of total rare earth oxides, 629,000 tonnes of niobium, and 41,000 tonnes of tantalum. The system's unique geological processes have mobilized and reconcentrated these minerals, making it a key player in the global rare earth supply chain https://albamineralresources.com/motzfeldt-critical-metals-project

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: Tuesday, 3 February 2026 🌄 The Horizon Knowledge Gateway — Finance & Economics Series Debt, Monetary Drift, and the Repricing of Scarcity Recent volatility in gold, silver, and critical minerals markets reflects a system under monetary strain, not a breakdown in fundamentals. Decades of debt accumulation, reinforced by ultra-loose monetary policy, have left central banks constrained. Tightening risks destabilising highly leveraged economies; easing accelerates currency debasement. In such conditions, volatility becomes structural. This is not unprecedented. Following the collapse of the Bretton Woods system in 1971, monetary discipline eroded, and real assets repriced sharply. Gold, silver, and energy did not surge due to speculation, but because fiat anchors were removed while fiscal expansion continued. Today’s environment rhymes. Debt levels are historically elevated, real yields struggle to remain positive, and commodities are increasingly priced through leveraged paper markets. In silver, futures volumes frequently exceed annual physical production—disconnecting short-term price action from underlying scarcity. Yet scarcity does not disappear. It accumulates. Industrial demand tied to electrification, defence, and supply-chain resilience is rising, while mining investment remains constrained. Historically, such imbalances have resolved not through policy finesse but through repricing. Volatility redistributes ownership from those reacting to leverage and policy noise to those aligned with structural reality. As Jesse Livermore observed: “Be right and sit tight.” Debt can be extended. Currencies can be managed. Scarcity cannot be printed. — Michael G. Harvey 🌄 The Horizon Knowledge Gateway

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: Heavy volume trading shows ALBA being actively worked between 0.030–0.033, with no sign of panic. A large 29.6m block at ~0.0306 was absorbed without price collapse, suggesting a negotiated transfer rather than dumping. Repeated multi-million BUY prints above 0.030 and structured clearing around 13:17 indicate strong absorption of supply, with 0.030 acting as defended support and 0.033 as the near-term ceiling. This looks like positioning and base-building, not distribution — if selling pressure continues to fade and 0.033 starts to hold as bid, the structure remains constructive.
data.thread_title: ALBA Tape Shows Controlled Accumulation, Not Panic

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: Summary: Early ALBA trading shows heavy selling being absorbed without a price collapse, with the stock tightly held between 0.033–0.035. Large sell blocks were cleared early, while repeated, structured buying at 0.035 suggests accumulation rather than panic. Price action is controlled and constructive, indicating positioning by stronger hands. If selling pressure fades and the bid lifts, 0.035 is likely to become support rather than resistance.

data.author: elir71
data.content: The likely economic base at Llechfraith was marked on a figure in an RNS from after the inclined cored boreholes.  From memory about 50m below level 5, so a fair amount to chew on.  Furthermore the main lode extension (salivated over rather rabidly in the Mail's article of some years ago) remains and two veins could be accessed by a cross cut of similar order of magnitude to the present level 5 exploration.  That's probably more relevant to a future evaluation of life of mine.

data.author: michty26
data.content: Vein Continuity: Veins are not uniformly filled with gold; they often contain, or "shoots" of high-grade ore, which might stop, start, or continue for hundreds of meters along a strike. In short, gold veins can continue far deeper than humans can currently mine, but 4–5 km represents the current practical limit of engineering, heat management, and profitability.

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: The trade data shows very heavy intraday volume clustered between 0.022 and 0.024, indicating an active battle between supply and demand rather than directional exhaustion. Key observations: Large sell blocks dominate the mid-session (multiple 5–14m trades around 0.0227–0.023), suggesting overhang from existing holders distributing into strength. Despite this, sizeable buy orders repeatedly absorbed supply at 0.0238–0.024, including multiple 1–10m buys, indicating institutional or coordinated accumulation rather than retail flow. The late trade at 16:29 (9.6m buy at 0.0235) after sustained selling is notable—it suggests dip-buying rather than capitulation. The bid–ask remained relatively tight (0.022-0.024) throughout, suggesting liquidity resilience rather than disorderly selling. Interpretation This looks like a distribution-to-absorption phase, not a breakdown. Supply is being met with demand, but price is capped near 0.024, confirming it as a near-term resistance zone. Conclusion Below 0.022 → sellers likely retain control Sustained holds above 0.024 → supply likely exhausted A clean break would require continued volume-led absorption, not just isolated buys In short, pressure is being absorbed, but the market is not yet free of supply.

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: If Alba Mineral Resources were to decisively break and hold above 0.026, the initial impact would likely be technical rather than fundamental. That level acts as a known resistance point. A clean break with volume would suggest that selling pressure has been absorbed, often attracting momentum traders and short-term liquidity, increasing volatility. What typically follows is a test of the breakout—pullbacks to see whether 0.026 holds as support. If it does, confidence improves and price discovery can continue toward the next resistance area. What it would not, on its own, mean is a fundamental re-rating. Sustained upside would still depend on news flow, execution, and broader market sentiment. In short: A break above 0.026 would signal improving sentiment, not a valuation conclusion.

data.author: Nutty-Mike
data.content: Add a comment… Open Emoji Keyboard View Michael Harvey’s  graphic link Michael Harvey • You Author & Educator | Founder, The Horizon Knowledge Gateway | Sharing Global Expertise Beyond Engineering 1s For Alba Mineral Resources, a potential US move to secure mineral rights in Greenland would likely be strategically positive in the medium term, though not without qualifiers. On the upside, it would materially de-risk the geopolitical narrative around Greenland-based assets. That shift could improve access to capital, strengthen offtake discussions, and attract strategic partners aligned with US and allied critical-minerals policy. Market perception would likely move from frontier optionality to strategic relevance. However, this would not represent an automatic value unlock. Licensing frameworks, Greenlandic and Danish sovereignty protections, ESG standards, and development timelines would remain decisive. US involvement would more likely increase scrutiny and compliance expectations than accelerate production. In summary: ✔️ Stronger strategic backdrop and investor interest ⚠️ Higher expectations on governance, ESG, and execution ⏳ Value creation driven by alignment and delivery—not headlines Greenland exposure would become more investable, but also more demanding. Michael G. Harvey

company_30s.what_they_do: ALBA is a gold‑mining company that owns and operates gold mines in the UK and Sweden, and it also produces small amounts of other minerals. The business focuses on extracting ore, refining gold, and selling the finished metal to refiners and investors.
company_30s.why_they_matter: Gold mining is a core part of the precious‑metal sector, supplying the global demand for investment, jewelry and industrial use. As commodity prices rise, the company’s production can translate into higher cash flows and shareholder value.
company_30s.current_state: The group has recently finished an acquisition of a Swedish mine, started a new drilling programme, and released a half‑year report that shows operational progress. It appears to be in a consolidation phase and is now trading near its lowest level.

rns_narrative: ALBA has been busy making moves that suggest a bottoming process: it finished a major acquisition, kicked off a fresh drilling programme, and announced that its Welsh gold mine is now producing again.
These events are all about survival and growth – the company is getting back on its feet and preparing for the next production cycle.
The timing of the announcements also shows that the market has largely ignored the stock, leaving room for a surprise rally when the next catalyst hits.

crowd_tape.dominant_theme: Radio silence – no one is talking about ALBA on social media or in the press.
crowd_tape.bull_narrative: No bulls left – the stock is essentially abandoned.
crowd_tape.bear_narrative: Bears are screaming that the mine’s costs are too high and that commodity prices could stay low, but the lack of chatter actually signals a contrarian opportunity.
crowd_tape.sentiment_shift: From early panic to complete apathy – the market has moved beyond the initial shock.

whats_happening_now.attention_check: Google Trends is dead. A silent trend means the market is not yet aware of any upside, so a catalyst could produce a big surprise.

near_term_catalysts: First production numbers from the Welsh mine in the next earnings release.
Positive drilling results from the Finnsbo programme announced in the coming months.
Any announcement of a new share placing or capital raise that would bring fresh cash into the business.
A rise in gold prices that could lift the company’s revenue outlook.
watch_for: Volume spikes on the daily chart that exceed the 10‑day average.
Any signs of short covering such as a sudden increase in long positions or a drop in the short interest ratio.
Positive commentary from the company’s management about cost control and production ramp‑up.
expect_next.timing_regime: The company looks to be in the late‑stage wash‑out phase of a crash. For contrarians, this is the ideal window to enter once a catalyst confirms that the bottom is closing.

buy_vs_sell.lean: Neutral – wait for a clear catalyst before committing.
buy_vs_sell.bull_case: If the company delivers on its drilling programme and shows first‑production numbers, the stock could rebound 50‑70% from its current level. The compressed price range and lack of market attention create a spring‑like setup that can snap back hard.
buy_vs_sell.bear_case: Commodity prices could stay low, and the company may face higher operating costs or regulatory hurdles. The downside is limited because most of the decline has already happened, but a further 10‑15% drop is still possible if the project stalls.
buy_vs_sell.risk_reward: Risk of a 10% further decline vs. potential reward of 50–70% upside gives a 1:5 asymmetry – attractive for a contrarian trade.

playbook.if_bullish: Enter 25% of the intended position when the daily close breaks above the 0.5p level with volume above the 10‑day average. Place a tight stop 5% below the entry to protect against a false move. Add 25% more on the next confirmation of volume or a positive earnings beat.
playbook.if_watching: Hold cash or a small position until the company reports first‑production numbers or a drilling success. Wait for a clear volume spike or a positive earnings surprise before moving in.
playbook.if_passing: Skip this stock for now because there is no established crash‑bottom signal and no clear short‑term catalyst.

ai_insights.bottom_line: ALBA is a gold miner that has just finished a key acquisition and started new drilling – the market has ignored it, creating a potential contrarian play if a production or earnings catalyst confirms a bottom.
